Package jetbrains.exodus.env

Interface Transaction

  • public interface Transaction
    Transaction is required for any access to data in database. Any transaction holds a database snapshot (version of the database), thus providing snapshot isolation.

    All changes made in a transaction are atomic and consistent if they are successfully flushed or committed. Along with snapshot isolation and configurable durability, transaction are fully ACID-compliant. By default, transaction durability is turned off since it significantly slows down flush()and commit(). To turn it on, pass true to EnvironmentConfig.setLogDurableWrite(boolean).

    Transactions can be read-only or not, exclusive or not. Read-only transactions are used to only read data. Exclusive transactions are used to have successive access to database. If you have an exclusive transaction, no other transaction (except read-only) can be started against the same Environment unless you finish (commit or abort) your exclusive one.

    Given you have an instance of Environment you can start new transaction: 

     final Transaction txn = environment.beginTransaction();
    Starting read-only transaction: 
     final Transaction txn = environment.beginReadonlyTransaction();
    Starting exclusive transaction: 
     final Transaction txn = environment.beginExclusiveTransaction();
    See Also:
    Environment, Environment.beginTransaction(), Environment.beginReadonlyTransaction(), Environment.beginExclusiveTransaction(), EnvironmentConfig.setLogDurableWrite(boolean)

    • Method Detail

      • isIdempotent

        boolean isIdempotent()
        Idempotent transaction changes nothing in database. It doesn't matter whether you flush it or revert, commit or abort. Result will be the same - nothing will be added, modified or deleted. Flushing idempotent transaction is trivial, flush() just does nothing and returns true. Each newly created transaction is idempotent.
        Returns:
        true if transaction is idempotent
        See Also:
        flush(), commit()

      • abort

        void abort()
        Drops all changes and finishes the transaction.
        See Also:
        commit(), flush(), revert(), isFinished()

      • commit

        boolean commit()
        Tries to flush all changes accumulated to the moment in the transaction and finish the transaction. If it returns true all changes are flushed and transaction is finished, otherwise nothing is flushed and transaction is not finished.
        Returns:
        true if transaction is committed
        See Also:
        flush(), abort(), revert(), isFinished()

      • flush

        boolean flush()
        Tries to flush all changes accumulated to the moment in the transaction. Returns true if flush succeeded. In that case, transaction remains unfinished and holds the newest database snapshot.
        Returns:
        true if transaction is flushed
        See Also:
        commit(), abort(), revert(), isFinished()

      • revert

        void revert()
        Drops all changes without finishing the transaction and holds the newest database snapshot.
        See Also:
        commit(), abort(), flush(), isFinished()

      • getSnapshot

        Transaction getSnapshot()
        Creates new transaction holding the same database snapshot as this one holds.
        Returns:
        new transaction holding the same database snapshot
        See Also:
        Environment.beginTransaction()

      • getSnapshot

        Transaction getSnapshot​(@Nullable
                        @Nullable java.lang.Runnable beginHook)
        Creates new transaction with specified begin hook holding the same database snapshot as this one holds.
        Parameters:
        beginHook - begin hook
        Returns:
        new transaction holding the same database snapshot
        See Also:
        Environment.beginTransaction(Runnable)

      • getReadonlySnapshot

        Transaction getReadonlySnapshot()
        Creates new read-only transaction holding the same database snapshot as this one holds.
        Returns:
        new read-only transaction holding the same database snapshot
        See Also:
        Environment.beginReadonlyTransaction()

      • getEnvironment

        @NotNull
@NotNull Environment getEnvironment()
        Returns:
        Environment instance against which the transaction was created.

      • setCommitHook

        void setCommitHook​(@Nullable
                   @Nullable java.lang.Runnable hook)
        Provides transaction with commit hook. Commit hook is called if and only if the transaction is going to be successfully flushed or committed. That is, hook.run() is called when you call flush() or commit(), and any of these methods will definitely succeed and return true.
        Parameters:
        hook - commit hook
        See Also:
        flush(), commit()

      • getStartTime

        long getStartTime()
        Time when the transaction acquired its database snapshot, i.e. time when it was started, reverted or successfully flushed (committed).
        Returns:
        the difference (in milliseconds) between current time and midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC.

      • getSnapshotId

        long getSnapshotId()
        Returns:
        the value of the snapshot id which is used to read data from transaction

      • isReadonly

        boolean isReadonly()
        Returns:
        true if the transaction is read-only.

      • isExclusive

        boolean isExclusive()
        Returns:
        true if the transaction was started as exclusive one
        See Also:
        Environment.beginExclusiveTransaction()

      • isFinished

        boolean isFinished()
        Returns:
        true if the transaction is finished, committed or aborted
        See Also:
        commit(), abort()

      • getUserObject

        @Nullable
@Nullable java.lang.Object getUserObject​(@NotNull
                                         @NotNull java.lang.Object key)
        Returns an user object identified by the specified key and bound to the transaction, or null if no object is bound to the transaction by the specified key.
        Parameters:
        key - a key identifying the user object
        Returns:
        an user object identified by the specified key and bound to the transaction

      • setUserObject

        void setUserObject​(@NotNull
                   @NotNull java.lang.Object key,
                   @NotNull
                   @NotNull java.lang.Object value)
        Bind an user object (value) identified by a key to the transaction.
        Parameters:
        key - a key identifying the user object
        value - user object bound to the transaction
